hawaiian_text: Noho ihola i laila, mahi ‘ai, ‘elua āna mau māla  ‘uala lō‘ihi e waiho nei ā hiki i kēia lā, a ua kapa ‘ia  ka inoa o ia mau māla, ‘o Nāmakaokapāo‘o ā hiki i  kēia lā. A o‘o ka ‘uala, ‘ōlelo ‘o Puali‘i i kāna ‘ōlelo   ho‘ohiki, “Aia ā kālua ke po‘o o ka ulua me ka ‘uala,  a ‘ai ‘o Puali‘i, a laila, noa, ‘ai kāna wahine, Pōka‘ī a  me nā mea ‘ē a‘e. No laila, iho akula ‘o Puali‘i i kai  o Honouliuli e lawai‘a i i‘a ‘ai pū me ka ‘uala.
llama-3.3-70B-Instruct_exl2_6.0bpw-maui_: Puali‘i lived there, farming, having two large sweet potato patches that remain until this day, and the name of those patches is Nāmakaokapāo‘o until this day. And when the sweet potatoes were ripe, Puali‘i would say in his habitual speech, “When the head of the ulua fish is cooked with the sweet potatoes, then Puali‘i eats, and his wife, Pōka‘ī, and their children, too, can eat without restriction.” Therefore, Puali‘i would go down to the sea at Honouliuli to fish for fish to eat with the sweet potatoes.

This passage offers a glimpse into the daily life of Puali‘i, a prominent figure in ancient Hawaiian society, highlighting his connection to the land, his role as a provider, and the cultural significance of food in Hawaiian culture. The text is rich in linguistic features and historical allusions that provide insight into the social and cultural context of the time.

From a linguistic perspective, the passage showcases the complexity and nuances of the Hawaiian language. The use of words like "māla" (patch or garden) and "‘uala" (sweet potato) demonstrates the importance of agriculture in Hawaiian society. The phrase "‘elua āna mau māla ‘uala lō‘ihi" (having two large sweet potato patches) illustrates the use of descriptive language to convey the abundance and size of the patches. The name "Nāmakaokapāo‘o" is also noteworthy, as it suggests a deep connection to the land and the passing down of names and places from one generation to the next.

The cultural context of the passage is equally significant. The mention of sweet potatoes as a staple food source highlights the importance of agriculture in Hawaiian society. The fact that Puali‘i has two large patches of sweet potatoes suggests his status as a provider and a leader in his community. The reference to the ulua fish, a species highly valued in Hawaiian culture, adds another layer of cultural significance to the passage. The combination of fish and sweet potatoes as a meal also underscores the importance of balancing protein sources with staple crops in the traditional Hawaiian diet.

The historical significance of this passage lies in its portrayal of daily life in ancient Hawaii. The text suggests a sense of self-sufficiency and community, with Puali‘i providing for his family and possibly his broader community through his farming and fishing activities. The mention of specific locations, such as Honouliuli, also provides valuable information about the geography and place names of ancient Hawaii.

Furthermore, the passage offers insight into the social dynamics of ancient Hawaiian society. The fact that Puali‘i's wife, Pōka‘ī, and their children are mentioned as beneficiaries of his labor highlights the importance of family and community in Hawaiian culture. The phrase "no laila, iho akula ‘o Puali‘i i kai o Honouliuli" (therefore, Puali‘i would go down to the sea at Honouliuli) suggests a sense of routine and responsibility, with Puali‘i undertaking his fishing trips to provide for his family.

In conclusion, this passage provides a unique window into the cultural, linguistic, and historical context of ancient Hawaii. Through its description of daily life, agricultural practices, and social dynamics, the text offers a rich and nuanced portrayal of Hawaiian society, highlighting the importance of family, community, and cultural traditions.

reference_translation: They lived there and farmed, and Puali‘i had two  long sweet potato patches that remain until today,  and the patches were given the name,   Nāmakaokapāo‘o until today. When the sweet  potatoes were mature, Puali‘i said made a  promise, saying, “I’ll cook the head of an ulua fish  in the imu along with some sweet potatoes. When  Puali‘i eats, then the food will be made free for his  woman, Pōka‘ī, and anyone else.” So, Puali‘i went  down to the shore of Honouliuli to fish for a catch  to eat with sweet potatoes.
reference_commentary: **Paragraph 4:**• Pua-li‘i is a farmer with 2 long sweet potato patches  that lasted until the publication of this story. The  name of this sweet potato garden was known as *Nā maka-o-ka-pāo‘o*, the name of Pō-ka-‘ī’s son, and  victorious hero of the story;  • When the sweet potatoes were ready for harvest,  Pua-li‘i said that when he eats ulua fish with sweet  potatoes, cooked in the imu. The food would then be  made free for others, particularly Pō-ka-‘ī and Nā maka-o-ka-pāo‘o after he eats.  – The emphasis on Pua-li‘i, a male and head of the  family, eating, with his woman and child being  allowed to eat separately after he was done, is a  custom of ‘Ai Kapu culture;  • Having announced the eating routine/schedule, Pua li‘i then went to Hono-uliuli (dark bay) to fish for  ulua.  – The choice of ulua to eat with the ‘uala (sweet  potato) is likely due to the similarity in the   pronunciation of the two words, signifying ʻwhat is  above, so below,’ an old and recurring esoteric  feature of Hawaiian prosidy and culture, with a  lesson that there should always be balance in life  and in human practices (above-below; left-right;  male-female). This is the essence of ʻpono’;
